Topic.Title: Linux Mint 14......Wow!

Message.Msg: People might thing about using Linux but as soon as they find out it doesn't run iTunes they are done with Linux. Big problem with Linux is: 1. Lacks critical mass. Windows runs just about anything that users want to run and Linux doesn't. 2. No good support 3. Too many flavors of Linux to choose so it is very confusing for the common user. 3. Linux community members are bad citizens who aren't really that helpful to new users. 4. confusing UI for such things as adding new drivers, adding and removing and removing applications. Most folks just don't want to take the time to learn the Linux way of doing things. Linux use is around 5% and has been that way for the last couple of years.

Message.Title: Long term underperformance?
Message.Msg: There is mantra about MSFT stock performance that has been repeated so often by bears that even some bull are brainwashed by it. The mantra is that MSFT has gone nowhere for the past 5 years and has underperformed the market. Quite honestly the market has gone nowhere in 5 years. So while technically true that MSFT has gone nowhere in 5 years what you have to look at is relative performance vs the S&P to see whether MSFT is underperforming or outperforming. Pull up a comparative chart of the S&P and MSFT over the past 5 years and you will see what I mean. In some years MSFT has underperformed the S&P and some years it has outperformed but by and large it has tracked the S&P. Over the past year it has underperformed but during the 2013 MSFT is outperforming the market and I expect that to continue. So MSFT goes through these periods of underperformance and outperformance but it is not a perpetual under performer that bears want you to believe.

Message.Title: Sun/Moon Cycles say S&P 500 should start dropping till 4/22
Message.Msg: We are at the peak of the current sun/moon cycle in the market. Be careful entering now at this stage of the cycle. Also, the 60-min chart of S&P is close to the confluence of the rising wedge pattern that should also coincide with the sun/moon cycle. Be careful on jumping in now, and wait for these two patterns to end.

Topic.Title: Linux Mint 14......Wow!

Message.Msg: If iTunes is critical to someone they'll just get a MAC and forget Windows altogether. The massive abundance of legacy Windows software is its greatest strength. But this strength only applies for traditional desktop apps which Microsoft no longer favors. When it comes to a new interface and new apps Android (Linux) and IOS are crushing Microsoft's Metro and its ecosystem. This is why it is in Microsoft's benefit to "fix" W8 for those that need or want to use traditional desktop apps while also giving Microsoft the greatest leverage. Microsoft's problem isn't lack of technology, it's arrogance and their absolute view that users must conform to their view of productivity.

Topic.Title: Linux Mint 14......Wow!

Message.Msg: "If iTunes is critical to someone they'll just get a MAC and forget Windows altogether." But that isn't what is happening. Sales of Mac are stagnating so folks still want their Windows apps but like iPhones so they want to load iTunes on Windows. "When it comes to a new interface and new apps Android (Linux) and IOS are crushing Microsoft's Metro and its ecosystem." Well, these are really just mobile OS's and have nothing to do with Linux and MAC and Windows Desktop proper. They have their root there but really you can't take an IOS app and load it on your Mac. It is true with WP8 too but mobile is a small but fast growing segment of Microsoft's business. WP O/S sales doubled year over year which is faster then IOS and android so your statement "crushing Microsoft Metro" is completely off base. "it's arrogance and their absolute view that users must conform to their view of productivity." That is your opinion but having worked in a Windows environment, working with Windows support people and sales people over a number of years as a career not a bystander, I have quite a different experience with Microsoft. They don't always get it right out of the box but they listen to their customers and correct their mistakes. If people turn out to not like Win8 then Microsoft will fix it very quickly. People hated Windows ME for good reason and it had a short lifespan.

Message.Title: This Stock will Explode this Afternoon Due to MSFT's Mediaroom Sale!
Message.Msg: It was just announced that MSFT has sold their Mediaroom IPTV multi-screen video business to ERIC for just under $200mm. It has clients like ATT Uverse and a reach of 11mm pay-TV subscribers. ERIC will now have a 25% multi-screen video market share, the largest in this space! CCUR is about to explode big time to $8 this afternoon and possibly $9 tomorrow as this news spreads! CCUR's MediaHawk multi-screen platform has technology that pay-TV providers rate a lot higher than Mediaroom, with two huge clients: Virgin Media the largest cable TV operator in the UK and Jupiter the largest cable TV operator in Japan. CCUR's MediaHawk delivers their TV and on demand content to the mobile devices of 6.3mm pay-TV subscribers or 57% of Mediaroom's reach. If Mediaroom was acquired for just under $200mm, CCUR's MediaHawk must be worth appx $100mm! Currently, CCUR extremely profitable video business is not receiving any value at all! CCUR at $6.98 with 8.72mm shares outstanding has a market cap of only $60.87mm with $24.6mm in cash and an enterprise value of only $36.27mm. After subtracting $15mm for the price CCUR paid to acquire their Media Data Intelligence business, CCUR is only receiving $21.27mm in value for their real-time and video delivery solutions businesses combined! CCUR's real-time business has been operating for 47 years, providing ultra high performance real-time technology for time critical simulation devices used by the military and auto makers. It has 4 of the world's 5 largest defense contractors as clients and current annualized revenue of $27.6mm. It's worth a minimum of $25mm, leaving zero value left for CCUR's video delivery business! For CCUR's video business with its MediaHawk technology to be worth $100mm, CCUR needs to rise by $11.47 or 164% to $18.45! CCUR could rise to $8 today, $9 tomorrow, and $10 Friday, before exploding to $15+ next week! CCUR earned non-GAAP EPS of $0.35 last year and will earn non-GAAP EPS of at least $0.50 this year!

Message.Title: PC Sales Plummet, W8 Is The Reason
Message.Msg: PC sales in first quarter down 14%, largest drop in two decades. According to IDC study "Windows 8 actually deterred potential PC buyers as users felt they could not afford touch-screen models required to make the most of Windows 8." Because Microsoft forced Windows 8 on non-touch screen devices and removed the traditional desktop PC buyers were left with no good option other than to postpone buying, buy MAC or an Android tablet. RT is useless and consumers figured this out fast. Fortunately for Microsoft, Intel is delivering so much innovation to the PC & tablet space Microsoft may get another chance at success. Microsoft needs to immediately fix Windows 8 and restore the W7 desktop for every PC user that wants it. They need to drastically cut the cost of Windows for the new class of Intel based Haswell and Baytrail tablets coming to the market and by doing this they may be able to compete against the same Intel powered tablets that will also be running Android, Ubuntu Touch and Tizen.

Message.Title: PCs hit by a huge 14% quarterly drop as Windows 8 flops
Message.Msg: On CNET now. Another indicator of the horrible mess that is windoze 8. I love it..... ====================================== International Data Corp. says first-quarter computer shipments tumbled 14 percent from the previous year, much worse than the estimated 7.7 percent slide. First-quarter global computer shipments dropped 14 percent from the previous year, the tech research firm said, much worse than its forecast for a 7.7 percent decline. The extent of the pullback marked the worst ever quarter since IDC began tracking quarterly PC shipments in 1994, and it's the fourth consecutive quarter of year-over-year shipment declines. All regions dropped in the period, despite improving economic conditions in some areas, IDC said. As if that wasn't enough, the main factor expected to boost the PC market -- the release of Microsoft's Windows 8 -- actually hurt computer shipments. And even if people desire PCs with touchscreens, they still cost too much and suffer from component shortages. IDC noted that innovations being pushed by PC makers are actually being viewed by consumers as "cumbersome or costly." ============================================

Message.Title: Struggling PC makers and Windows 8 push PC market into free fall
Message.Msg: Just to rub it in..... =================================================== IDG News Service - A "perfect storm" of struggling PC companies, aversion to Windows 8 and wider mobile-device adoption plunged the already struggling PC market into a free fall during the first quarter this year, IDC said. Worldwide PC shipments in the first quarter totaled 76.3 million units, down 13.9% compared to the same quarter last year, IDC said in research released on Wednesday. The decline was worse than 7.7% previously forecast by the analyst firm. PC shipments fell across all regions worldwide, and the market is headed into a further contraction than previously expected, IDC said in a statement. Windows 8 also did little to help PC shipments grow, IDC analysts said. Fewer consumers are upgrading PCs to Windows 8, while businesses are largely sticking with Windows 7 as the new OS does not fit into their usage model. Windows 8 has not been successful among mobile or desktop users, who have struggled adapting to its touch-based user interface, Daoud said, adding that users are also missing the Start button. Microsoft has to take quick corrective action to help the PC market, he said. ===================================================

Message.Title: Windows 8 has put the world's PC market to sleep - IDC
Message.Msg: I just love reiterating the w8 disaster. ============================================================ The global PC market is dwindling, and Windows 8 could be to blame, according to the beancounters at IDC. The analyst firm released its rundown of global PC shipments on Tuesday, and the year-on-year double digit decline blows a cold wind for traditional PC makers like Dell and HP, and OS-slinger Microsoft. "It seems clear that the Windows 8 launch not only failed to provide a positive boost to the PC market, but appears to have slowed the market," Bob O'Donnell, IDC's program vice president for clients and displays, said in a canned statement. "While some consumers appreciate the new form factors and touch capabilities of Windows 8, the radical changes to the UI, removal of the familiar Start button, and the costs associated with touch have made PCs a less attractive alternative to dedicated tablets and other competitive devices. Microsoft will have to make some very tough decisions moving forward if it wants to help reinvigorate the PC market." Ouch. ==============================================================

Topic.Title: PC Sales Plummet, W8 Is The Reason

Message.Msg: In its tally, IDC excludes tablets, even if they run PC-style software. It also excludes any device that has a detachable keyboard. With the release of Windows 8, PC makers have been reviving their experiments with tablet-laptop hybrids, some of which have detachable keyboards. Consumers are likely to have shifted some of their buying away from traditional laptops and toward these new devices, which means that the total sales decline of Windows-based devices may not be quite as drastic as IDC's numbers suggest.

Message.Title: All signs so far point to Windows 8 being a flop
Message.Msg: "Unfortunately, it seems clear that the Windows 8 launch not only didn't provide a positive boost to the PC market, but appears to have slowed the market," IDC Vice President Bob O'Donnell said. The newest version of Windows is designed to work well with touch-sensitive screens, but the displays add to the cost of a PC. Together, the changes and higher prices "have made PCs a less attractive alternative to dedicated tablets and other competitive devices," O'Donnell said. First-quarter shipments of PCs fell 14 percent worldwide from the same time last year, according to International Data Corp. That's the deepest quarterly drop since the firm started tracking the industry in 1994. Another research firm, Gartner Inc., pegged the first-quarter decline at 11 percent.

Topic.Title: All signs so far point to Windows 8 being a flop

Message.Msg: IDC released its 2013 first quarter PC shipment estimates that are pretty brutal for four of the top five vendors; HP down 24% year over year, Dell down 11%, Acer down 31% and ASUS down 19%.
